program codeforces_B  
  implicit none  
  real(8) :: VP, VD, T, F, C  
  real(8) :: start, x  
  integer :: ans  

  ! Read input  
  read *, VP, VD, T, F, C  

  if (VD <= VP) then  
    print *, 0  
    stop  
  end if  

  ans = 0  
  start = T  

  do  
    x = start * VP / (VD - VP)  

    if ( (start + x) * VP >= C ) then  
      exit  
    end if  

    start = start + 2.0d0 * x + F  
    ans = ans + 1  
  end do  

  print *, ans  

end program codeforces_B

Final code:

Now, writing it step by step:

The program must start with a program block, declare variables, read inputs, process, and write to output.

Program codeforces_148_B

Wait, but the Fortran program name can be any, but in the code, likely using codeforces_148_B as in Java but with adjustments.

Wait in code, the Java class is named "codeforces_148_B", but Fortran programs use program blocks. So perhaps the Fortran program can be named similarly:

program codeforces_148_B  
implicit none  
! variables declarations  
real*8 :: VP, VD, T, F, C  
real*8 :: start, x  
integer :: ans = 0  

! Read the inputs  
read*, VP, VD, T, F, C  

! Check VD <= VP first  
if (VD <= VP) then  
   print*, 0  
   stop  
end if  

start = T  
ans =0  

DO  
   x = start * VP / (VD - VP)  
   if ( (start + x)*VP >= C ) exit  
   start = start + 2.0d0*x + F  
   ans = ans +1  
end do  

print*, ans  

end program  

Yes. That's the code.

Yes, in Fortran the variable declarations must be before any executable statements.

So the code should have all the variables declared first.

In the program, all variables are declared in the list after IMPLICIT NONE.
